description.summary: A Japanese smoke spirit or yokai made entirely of smoke and vapor with no solid body. Generally neutral in nature and visible only to the pure-hearted or those fated to die.
description.full: The Enenra is a relatively obscure Japanese yokai that takes the form of smoke or vapor. Unlike most yokai, it has no solid physical form and exists entirely as smoke, constantly shifting and changing shape. The Enenra typically manifests in smoke rising from wood fires, bonfires, or fireplaces, sometimes taking vague human shapes within the smoke. According to folklore, the Enenra is generally neutral rather than malevolent, and can only be seen by individuals who are pure of heart or those who are fated to die soon. The creature embodies the ephemeral and impermanent nature of existence, serving as a living metaphor for the transient quality of life itself. In modern popular culture, the Enenra has gained recognition through the Mortal Kombat character Smoke, who possesses smoke-based powers inspired by this yokai.

etymology.origin: From Japanese folklore. The name derives from Japanese words for smoke and mist.
etymology.meaning: 'En' (煙) means smoke, with 'enra' suggesting billowing or swirling patterns of smoke

physical.form: Composed entirely of smoke and vapor

features.description: Body made of smoke, vapor, and mist
Sometimes takes vague human shape within smoke
Often appears as shapeless smoke patterns

physical.morphology: Intangible smoke entity with no fixed form, existing as patterns and shapes within smoke and vapor

abilities.description: Completely incorporeal, cannot be physically harmed or touched
Can alter form within smoke, sometimes suggesting human shapes
Can only be seen by pure-hearted individuals or those fated to die
Appears in smoke from fires, particularly wood smoke

range.description: Traditional Japanese folklore, no specific geographic concentration within Japan.

origins.cultural_roots: Japanese yokai tradition, particularly Edo period yokai literature. Represents natural phenomena and the ephemeral nature of existence.
origins.earliest_accounts: Edo period yokai encyclopedias and illustrated scrolls.
origins.folklore_connections: Part of broader tradition of elemental and nature spirits in Japanese folklore.

timeline.significance: Enenra documented in yokai encyclopedias and illustrations

history.modern_era: The Enenra remains a relatively obscure yokai but gained modern recognition through video games (particularly Mortal Kombat's Smoke character) and anime/manga featuring smoke-based powers and smoke spirits.

folklore.beliefs: The Enenra embodies the concept of impermanence (mujō) central to Japanese Buddhist philosophy. Its smoke form represents the transient, ever-changing nature of existence.

japanese_cultural_context.significance: Though obscure, the Enenra exemplifies Japanese appreciation for subtle, ephemeral phenomena and the philosophical concept of impermanence (mujō).
japanese_cultural_context.sensitivity_note: The Enenra is part of traditional Japanese cultural heritage. Approach with respect for Japanese folklore traditions.
japanese_cultural_context.philosophical_connections: Relates to Buddhist concepts of impermanence and the transient nature of all things

folkloric.description: The Enenra represents the personification of smoke itself, giving form and consciousness to an insubstantial element

philosophical.description: Enenra embodies Buddhist concept of mujō (impermanence) - constantly changing, never solid, ultimately insubstantial
